utterances: Well, that's only the first phase.
First thing we want to do is get some people to communicate with us at that level, and then we have to start laying out what the qualifications are.
I read that you want someone who looks like Robert Redford, because you're also trying to raise money on this, right?
I mean, you need someone to represent you.
Yeah, we have a lot of services in kind and product sponsors, but we have not been able to find the revenue sponsor...
And it cost money to go out and run this thing on the desert.
Yeah.
And if my age is the impeding factor, then we'll take that factor out of there, and we'll find someone that is very qualified and we'll put them there and let them go ahead and set the record.
You're 66 and...
Right.
You're looking for someone a little bit younger to run this thing.
Well, if that's what a sponsor requires.
Yeah.
If a sponsor doesn't require that, then to heck with them.
I'm keeping the ride to myself.
You've driven it.
What's it like?
I've driven it 19 times, and it's smooth as a Cadillac.
Smooth as a Cadillac?
Yeah.
It's got aluminum wheels.
It doesn't even have rubber tires on it.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Yeah, it's very strong.
It's quite controllable.
It feels very comfortable when you're going fast.
I actually enjoyed driving it.
It's really a fun ride and it isn't hectic.
It isn't like driving, you know, like a gasser or something where you have to be correcting every small movement.
It's 50-feet long, something like that?
Yes, 56 feet, 6 inches.
How many horsepower in this baby?
The stock engine that we're running is - equates to about 42,500 horsepower.
Forty-two thousand horsepower.
Yeah.
That's got to be fast.
Well, that isn't enough.
We have a hopped-up engine that the S&S Turbine Services has in the wings waiting for us and it makes about 55,000.
You know, Ed, here you are.
You've been working on this for ten years, I guess, to get this point.
Yeah.
You've actually got this thing.
It really was a jet fighter plane at one point.
Yes.
It was an F-104 Starfighter and it's lived its life at Edwards Air Force Base from 1957 to 1970.
And it was flown by the who's-whos of aviation.
So, it's just quite a significant aircraft, and the fact that its tail number is 763 and the world land-speed record is 763 seems to me like that might be some divine intervention there.
How long does it take from when you start your run until you finish it?
Oh, it's about 20 seconds.
And in that time, you'll get up to 763-plus miles an hour.
You know, you accelerate real hard for about the first five miles and then you - if you're running at full speed, it'll cover the - one mile in about 4.3 seconds.
And then you take about another five or six miles to get stopped, and it - you know, everything starts slowing down and you kind of come idling to stop and that's it.
Ed, you know, I recall, when I was a boy and a young man, reading stories about the land-speed record.
And then I think it was 300, 400 miles an hour, and it seemed kind of, you know, barely possible.
But these kinds of speeds are just - they're just crazy.
Why are you doing something like this?
Well, I mean, your point, I think, is that the base of the party is strongly opposed to abortion rights.
But here is the thing.
There is no strong candidate at the moment among the Republicans, no dominant candidate.
Even as Giuliani has the lead, there's no, you know, President Bush running for election.
There's no Vice President Cheney trying to move up.
Now, what you're starting to see though is that his opponents - Giuliani's opponents on the Republican side - sees some blood in the water, Madeleine.
And so they are trying to worsen his problem here by pointing out that, as John McCain says, there's a fundamental conservative principle which protects the dignity of life.
Or Sam Brownback, another candidate, says during the debate, it was a glorious day - it would be a glorious day if the court were to overturn Roe V.
Wade.
Tom Tancredo, another candidate, talks about abortion as a culture of death and asks how the Republican Party could possibly have a candidate who would be supportive of abortion rights.
Okay, well, what about Mitt Romney?
He's also one who's had various positions, shall we say, on abortion.
His wife made a donation to Planned Parenthood.
You know, are people calling him a flip-flopper?
Well, that's exactly right.

Now, he had a very interesting response, which is he said Ronald Reagan did much the same thing, to change positions, and it's a matter of conscience and he's not going to apologize for moving towards a position that he now feels comfortable with.
So he's going off to try to give more speeches to groups that oppose abortion rights to sort of emphasize his position now.
But I think it's a weak point for him.
It's a bigger problem, obviously, for Giuliani, because Giuliani is reluctant to say that he has shifted his position of supporting a woman's right to choose.
And in fact, there's an '89 video playing to quite some popularity on YouTube in which you can see Giuliani saying that he believes that poor women should have funding, public funding, for abortions.
Okay, let's move on to news out of Washington.
And the House last night passing a second Iraq spending bill, but this also has a threat of a presidential veto.
You spent some time on the Hill this week.
What is Speaker Pelosi thinking?
Strong message.
Democrats want to end the war.
And an unpopular war.
She knows that in terms of the polls, you know, there's hardly any risk, and especially among Democrats, four to one, they oppose the war.
Even among swing voters, there's no risk, they're two to one opposed to the war.
So she feels like, you know what, she's got a clear path here.

The only problem would be if the president was able to persuade people that they weren't supporting the troops, the Democrats, and she's saying no, we'll give you some funding for the troops but we're not going to give you a blank check for this war.
What about benchmarks?
The president is now saying something that he'll approve benchmarks.

Well, benchmarks, you know, Madeleine, benchmarks without much teeth, benchmarks in terms of getting the Iraqi government to take some steps, but the consequence would only be withdrawal of funding aid to Iraq.
Okay.
NPR senior correspondent Juan Williams.
Thank you as always.
You're welcome, Madeleine.
I have a 14-year-old.
I would not want him to be governor of Vermont (laughter) or any other state.
But let me turn us to the balance of the U.S.
Supreme Court, which is of course a big issue for senators up for re-election this year.
President Trump's nominee for the court, Judge Brett Kavanaugh, will be on Capitol Hill tomorrow meeting with two of them - Senators Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota and Joe Donnelly of Indiana.
These are both Democrats trying to get elected again in states that Trump won, so they are seen as vulnerable and as potentially persuadable.
As NPR's Sarah McCammon reports, a lot of money and manpower is being used to sway senators caught in the middle.
